Award.AwardTitle: RCN: Integrating the Ecology and Evolution of Invasions: A Predictive Framework and Collaborative Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
RCN: Integrating the ecology and evolution of invasions: a predictive framework and collaborative approach

Determining the factors that enable introduced species to proliferate and become invasive is a fundamental challenge to ecologists and evolutionary biologists worldwide. This award will create a research coordination network (RCN) with the goal of improving our synthetic understanding of biological invasions, particularly with respect to the interplay among mechanisms of biotic resistance, enemy release, adaptive evolution, and hybridization. This RCN will seek a predictive framework to better integrate these hypotheses for invasions, and to clarify their predictions. The network will sponsor annual round tables, coordinate diverse research projects, and develop teaching modules for high schools. It will also sponsor symposia at scientific meetings and research exchanges to promote student and postdoc training and link groups working on similar issues. Training of students will seek to increase diversity through special efforts to engage Native American and African American undergraduates in research, teaching and management. The network will also develop a geo-referenced website, and cultivate media liaisons to connect the public with science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Invasive species are a major worldwide problem, which costs the US economy alone an estimated $120 billion annually. Not all introduced species become invasive, and thus understanding what factors facilitate invasion success and why some species become invasive remains a major scientific challenge. Because invasions are explicitly spacial, it is critical that we collaborate across political borders to tackle the problems they pose. Through this National Science Foundation Research Coordination Network grant, we developed the Global Invasions Network (http://invasionsrcn.si.edu/), which brought together over 60 scientists from 15 countries across six continents.

Intellectual Merit. We developed and published an approach to combining disparate research directions (ecological/environmental to genetic) to more effectively understand and predict invasion success. Using our global influence, we initiated the Global Garlic Mustard Field Survey, a project that leveraged citizen science and undergraduate learning institutions to compare the success of an invasive species that is wide-spread across the introduced U.S. with populations from it’s native European range. Data were collected by 164 people including citizens, volunteer scientists, and student groups from 16 countries in North America and Europe consisting of 45,788 measurements and counts of 137,811 plants. All field data and seed resources are being curated for release to the scientific community. This, an other project, have contributed to 70 publications.

Broader impacts. Our global network has stimulated significant ongoing collaboration and educational opportunities for students and early-career scientists within the US, and helped them gain international recognition and initiate national and international collaborations. These collaborations, and others among more senior scientists, have resulted in numerous publications to better understand what facilitates invasive species and provide insight into managing this important environmental problem.
